verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:4
verses.text: Very gently, but with prescient genius, he adopts this plan of tracing the origin and all the force of heresies to "philosophy falsely so called".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:5
verses.text: The existence of this "cloud of locusts" is  evidence of the antagonism of Satan;  of the prophetic spirit of the apostles;  of the tremendous ferment produced by the Gospel leaven as soon as it was hid in the "three measures of meal" by "the Elect Lady," the Ecclesia Dei;  of the fidelity of the witnesses,—that grand, heroic glory of the Ante-Nicene Fathers,—who never suffered these heresies to be mistaken for the faith, or to corrupt the Scriptures; and  finally of the power of the Holy Spirit, who gave them victory over errors, and enabled them to define truth in all the crystalline beauty of that "Mountain of Light," that true Koh-i-noor, the Nicene Symbol.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:6

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:54
verses.text: But I must here note, that as "words are things," and as infinite damage has been done to history and to Christian truth by tolerating this empiricism of Rome, I have restored scientific accuracy, in this series, whenever reference is made to the primitive bishops of Rome, who were no more "Popes" than Cincinnatus was an emperor.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:55
verses.text: It is time that theological science should accept, like other sciences, the language of truth and the terminology of demonstrated fact.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:56
verses.text: The early bishops of Rome were geographically important, and were honoured as sitting in the only apostolic see of the West; but they were almost inconsiderable in the structural work of the ante-Nicene ages, and have left no appreciable impress on its theology.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:57
verses.text: After the Council of Nice they were recognised as patriarchs, though equals among brethren, and nothing more.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:58

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:71
verses.text: Why, then, keep up the language of fiction and imposture, so confusing to young students? I believe the youthful Oxonians whom our modern Tertullian carried with him into the papal schism, could never have been made dupes but for the persistent empiricism of orthodox writers who practically adopt in words what they refute in argument, calling all bishops of Rome "Popes," and even including St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:72
verses.text: Peter's blessed name in this fallacious designation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:73
verses.text: In this series I adhere to the logic of facts, calling  all the bishops of Rome from Linus to Sylvester simply bishops; and  all their successors to Nicholas I.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:74

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:75
verses.text: Nicholas, who trampled on the Nicene Constitutions, and made the false decretals the canon law of the Western churches, was therefore the first "Pope" who answers to the Tridentine definitions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:76

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:81
verses.text: )  Here begins that "duplicating of our knowledge" of primitive Rome of which Bunsen speaks so justly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:82
verses.text: A thorough mastery of this book will prepare us to understand the great Cyprian in all his relations with the Roman Province, and not less to comprehend the affairs of Novatian.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:83
verses.text: Bunsen, with all respect, does not comprehend the primitive system, and reads it backward, from the modern system, which travesties antiquity even in its apparent conformities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:84
verses.text: These conformities are only the borrowing of old names for new contrivances.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:85
verses.text: Thus, he reads the cardinals of the eleventh century into the simple presbytery of comprovincial bishops of the third century, just as he elsewhere lugs in the Ave Maria of modern Italy to expound the Evening Hymn to the Trinity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:86
verses.text: In a professed Romanist, like De Maistre, this would be resented as jugglery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:87
verses.text: But let us come to facts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:88
verses.text: Bunsen's preliminary remarks are excellent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:89
verses.text: But when he comes to note an "exceptional system" in the Roman "presbytery," he certainly confuses all things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:90
verses.text: Let us recur to Tertullian.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:91
verses.text: See how much was already established in his day, which the Council of Nicaea recognised a century later as (τὰ ἀρχαῖα ἔθη) old primitive institutions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:92
verses.text: In all things the Greek churches were the exemplar and the model for other churches to follow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:93
verses.text: "Throughout the provinces of Greece," he says, "there are held, in definite localities, those councils," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:94
verses.text: "If we also, in our diverse provinces, observe," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:95
verses.text: Now, these councils, or "meetings," in spite of the emperors or the senate who issued mandates against them, as appears from the same passage, were, in the Roman Province, made up of the comprovincial bishops: and their gatherings seem to have been called "the Roman presbytery;" for, as is evident, the bishops and elders were alike called "presbyters," the word being as common to both orders as the word pastors or clergymen in our days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:96
verses.text: According to the thirty-fourth of the "Canons Apostolical," as Bunsen remarks, "the bishops of the suburban towns, including Portus, also formed at that time an integral part of the Roman presbytery".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:97
verses.text: This word also refers to all the presbyters of the diocese of Rome itself; and I doubt not originally the laity had their place, as they did in Carthage:  "the apostles, elders, and brethren" being the formula of Scripture; or, "with the whole Church," which includes them,—omni plebe adstante.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:98
verses.text: Now, all this accounts, as Bunsen justly observes, for the fact that one of the "presbytery" should be thus repeatedly called presbyter and "at the same time have the charge of the church at Portus, for which (office) there was no other title than the old one of bishop; for such was the title of every man who presided over the congregation in any city,—at Ostia, at Tusculum, or in the other suburban cities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:99
verses.text: Now let us turn to the thirty-fourth "Apostolical Canon" (so called), and note as follows:  "It is necessary that the bishops of every nation should know who is chief among them, and should recognise him as their head by doing nothing of great moment without his consent; and that each of them should do such things only as pertain to his own parish and the districts under him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:100
verses.text: And neither let him do any thing without the consent of all, for thus shall there be unity of heart, and thus shall God be glorified through our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:101
verses.text: I do not pause to expound this word parish, for I am elucidating Hippolytus by Bunsen's aid, and do not intend to interpolate my own theory of the primitive episcopate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:102
verses.text: Let the "Apostolical Constitutions" go for what they are worth: I refer to them only under lead of Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:103
verses.text: Bunsen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:104
verses.text: But now turn to the Nicene Council (Canon VI.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:105
verses.text: ) as follows: "Let the ancient customs prevail in Egypt, Libya, and Pentapolis, so that the Bishop of Alexandria have jurisdiction in all these provinces, since the like is customary in Rome also.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:106
verses.text: Likewise in Antioch and the other provinces, let the churches retain their privileges".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:107
verses.text: Here the Province of Rome is recognised as an ancient institution, while its jurisdiction and privileges are equalized with those of other churches.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:108
verses.text: Now, Rufinus, interpreting this canon, says it means, "the ancient custom of Alexandria and Rome shall still be observed; that the one shall have the care or government of the Egyptian, and the other that of the suburbicary churches".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:109
verses.text: Bunsen refers us to Bingham, and from him we learn that the suburbicary region, as known to the Roman magistrates, included only "a hundred miles about Rome".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:110
verses.text: This seems to have been canonically extended even to Sicily on the south, but certainly not to Milan on the north.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:111
verses.text: Suffice it, Hippolytus was one of those suburbicarian bishops who sat in the Provincial Council of Rome; without consent of which the Bishop of Rome could not, canonically, do anything of importance, as the canon above cited ordains.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:112
verses.text: Such are the facts necessary to a comprehension of conflicts excited by "the contemporaneous heresy," here noted.

verses.text: Wordsworth gives an ingenious explanation of this usage.

verses.text: But it seems to me to be based upon the relations of Hippolytus as one of the synod or "presbytery," without consent of which the bishop could do nothing important.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:119
verses.text: Zephyrinus, on the contrary, imagined himself competent to decide as to the orthodoxy of a tenet or of a teacher, without his comprovincials.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:120
verses.text: This, too, relieves our author from the charge of egotism when he exults in the defeat of such a bishop.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:121
verses.text: He says, it is true, "Callistus threw off Sabellius through fear of me," and we may readily believe that; but he certainly means to give honour to others in the Province when he says, "We resisted Zephyrinus and Callistus;" "We nearly converted Sabellius;" "All were carried away by the hypocrisy of Callistus, except ourselves".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:122
verses.text: This man cried out to his episcopal brethren, "Ye are Ditheists," apparently in open council.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:123
verses.text: His council prevailed over him by the wise leadership of Hippolytus, however; and he says of the two guilty bishops, "Never, at any time, have we been guilty of collusion with them".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:124
verses.text: They only imagined, therefore, that they were managing the "affairs of the Church".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:125
verses.text: The fidelity of their comprovincials preserved the faith of the Apostles in apostolic Rome.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:126

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:127
verses.text: (We offered them opposition, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:128
verses.text: )  Here we see that Hippolytus had no idea of the sense some put upon the convenire of his master Irenaeus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:129
verses.text: It was not "necessary" for them to conform their doctrines to that of the Bishop of Rome, evidently; nor to "the Church of Rome" as represented by him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:130
verses.text: To the church which presided over a province, indeed, recourse was to be had by all belonging to that province; but it is our author's grateful testimony, that to the council of comprovincials, and not to any one bishop therein, Rome owed its own adhesion to orthodoxy at this crisis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:131
verses.text: All this illustrates the position of Tertullian, who never thinks of ascribing to Rome any other jurisdiction than that belonging to other provinces.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:132
verses.text: As seats of testimony, the apostolic sees, indeed, are all to be honoured.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:133
verses.text: "In Greece, go to Corinth; in Asia Minor, to Ephesus; if you are adjacent to Italy, you have Rome; whence also (an apostolic) authority is at hand for us in Africa".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:134
verses.text: Such is his view of "contemporaneous affairs".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:137
verses.text: )  "Well might he weep," says Tayler Lewis, "as Lucian represents him, over his overflowing universe of perishing phenomena, where nothing stood;…nothing was fixed, but, as in a mixture, all things were confounded".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:138
verses.text: He was "the weeping philosopher".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:139
verses.text: Here let me add Henry Nelson Coleridge's remarks on the Greek seed-plot of those philosophies which were begotten of the Egyptian mysteries, and which our author regards as, in turn, engendering "all heresies," when once their leaders felt, like Simon Magus, a power in the Gospel of which they were jealous, and of which they wished to make use without submitting to its yoke.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:140
verses.text: "Bishop Warburton," says Henry Nelson Coleridge, "discovered, perhaps, more ingenuity than sound judgment in his views of the nature of the Greek mysteries; entertaining a general opinion that their ultimate object was to teach the initiated a pure theism, and to inculcate the certainty and the importance of a future state of rewards and punishments.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:141
verses.text: I am led by the arguments of Villoison and Ste.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:142
verses.text: Croix to doubt the accuracy of this".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:143
verses.text: In short, he supposes a "pure pantheism," or Spinosism, the substance of their teaching.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:144
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:145
verses.text: (Imagine themselves to be disciples of Christ, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:146
verses.text: )  This and the foregoing chapter offer us a most overwhelming testimony to the independence of councils.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:147
verses.text: In the late "Council of Sacristans" at the Vatican, where truth perished, Pius IX.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:148
verses.text: refused to all the bishops of what he accounted "the Catholic universe" what the seven suburbicarian bishops were able to enforce as a right, in the primitive age, against two successive Bishops of Rome, who were patrons of heresy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:149
verses.text: These heretical prelates persisted; but the Province remained in communion with the other apostolic provinces, while rejecting all communion with them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:150
verses.text: All this will help us in studying Cyprian's treatise On Unity, and it justifies his own conduct.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:151
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:152
verses.text: (The episcopal throne, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:153
verses.text: )  The simple primitive cathedra, of which we may learn something from the statue of Hippolytus, was, no doubt, "a throne" in the eyes of an ambitious man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:154
verses.text: Callistus is here charged, by one who knew him and his history, with obtaining this position by knavish words and practices.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:155
verses.text: The question may well arise, in our Christian love for antiquity, How could such things be, even in the age of martyrdoms? Let us recollect, that under the good Bishop Pius, when his brother wrote the Hermas, the peril of wealth and love of money began to be imminent at Rome.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:156
verses.text: Tertullian testifies to the lax discipline of that see when he was there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:157
verses.text: Minucius Felix lets us into the impressions made by the Roman Christians upon surrounding heathen: they were a set of conies burrowing in the earth; a "light-shunning people," lurking in the catacombs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:158
verses.text: And yet, while this fact shows plainly that good men were not ambitious to come forth from these places of exile and suffering, and expose themselves needlessly to death, it leads us to comprehend how ambitious men, studiosi novarum rerum, could remain above ground, conforming very little to the discipline of Christ, making friends with the world, and yet using their nominal religion on the principle that "gain is godliness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:159
verses.text: There were some wealthy Christians; there were others, like Marcia in the palace, sufficiently awakened to perceive their own wickedness, and anxious to do favours to the persecuted flock, by way, perhaps, of compounding for sins not renounced.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:160
verses.text: And when we come to the Epistles of Cyprian, we shall see what opportunities were given to desperate men to make themselves a sort of brokers to the Christian community; for selfish ends helping them in times of peril, and rendering themselves, to the less conscientious, a medium for keeping on good terms with the magistrates.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:161
verses.text: Such a character was Callistus, one of "the grievous wolves" foreseen by St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:162
verses.text: Paul when he exhorted his brethren night and day, with tears, to beware of them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:163
verses.text: How he made himself Bishop of Rome, the holy Hippolytus sufficiently explains.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:164
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:165
verses.text: (Unskilled in ecclesiastical definitions, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:166
verses.text: )  It has been sufficiently demonstrated by the learned Döllinger, than whom a more competent and qualified witness could not be named, that the late pontiff, Pius IX.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:167
verses.text: , was in this respect, as a bishop, very much like Callistus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:168
verses.text: Moreover, his chief adviser and prime minister, Antonelli, was notoriously Callistus over again; standing towards him in the same relations which Callistus bore to Zephyrinus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:169
verses.text: Yet, by the bull Ineffabilis, that pontiff has retrospectively clothed the definitions of Zephyrinus and Callistus with infallibility; thus making himself also a partaker in their heresies, and exposing himself to the anathemas with which the Catholic councils overwhelmed his predecessor Honorius and others.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:170
verses.text: That at such a crisis the testimony of Hippolytus should come to light, and supply a reductio ad absurdum to the late papal definitions, may well excite such a recognition of divine providence as Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:171
verses.text: Bunsen repeatedly suggests.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:172
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:173
verses.text: (All consented—we did not, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:174
verses.text: )  The Edinburgh editor supposes that the use of the plural we, in this place, is the official plural of a bishop.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:175
verses.text: It has been already explained, however, that he is speaking of the provincial bishops with whom he withstood Callistus when the plebs were carried away by his hypocrisy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:176
verses.text: In England, bishops in certain cases, are a "corporation sole;" and, as such, the plural is legal phraseology.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:177
verses.text: All bishops, however, use the plural in certain documents, as identifying themselves with the universal episcopate, on the Cyprianic principle—Episcopatus unus est, etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:178
verses.text: In Acts v.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:179
verses.text: is a passage which may be somewhat explained, perhaps, by this: "All consented…we did not".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:180
verses.text: The plebs joined themselves to the apostles; "but of the rest durst no man join himself to them: howbeit, the plebs magnified them, and believers were added," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:181
verses.text: "The rest" (τῶν δὲ λοιπῶν) here means the priests, the Pharisees, and Sadducees, the classes who were not the plebs, as appears by what immediately follows.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:182
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:183
verses.text: (Our condemnatory sentence, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:184
verses.text: )  Again: Hippolytus refers to the action of the suburbicarian bishops in provincial council.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:185
verses.text: And here is the place to express dissatisfaction with the apologetic tone of some writers, who seem to think Hippolytus too severe, etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:186
verses.text: As if, in dealing with such "wolves in sheep's clothing," this faithful leader could show himself a true shepherd without emphasis and words of abhorrence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:187
verses.text: Hippolytus has left to the Church the impress of his character as "superlatively sweet and amiable".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:188
verses.text: Such was St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:189
verses.text: John, the beloved disciple; but he was not less a "son of thunder".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:190
verses.text: Our Divine Master was "the Lamb," and "the Lion;" the author of the Beatitudes, and the author of those terrific woes; the "meek and gentle friend of publicans and sinners," and the "lash of small cords" upon the backs of those who made His Father's house a "den of thieves".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:191
verses.text: Such was Chrysostom, such was Athanasius, such was St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:192
verses.text: Paul, and such have ever been the noblest of mankind; tender and considerate, gentle and full of compassion; but not less resolute, in the crises of history, in withstanding iniquity in the persons of arch-enemies of truth, and setting the brand upon their foreheads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:193
verses.text: Good men, who hate strife, and love study and quiet, and to be friendly with others; men who never permit themselves to indulge a personal enmity, or to resent a personal affront; men who forgive injuries to the last farthing when they only are concerned,—may yet crucify their natures in withstanding evil when they are protecting Christ's flock, or fulfilling the command to "contend earnestly for the faith once delivered to the saints".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:194
verses.text: What the Christian Church owes to the loving spirit of Hippolytus in the awful emergencies of his times, protecting the poor sheep, and grappling with wolves for their sake, the Last Day will fully declare.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:195
verses.text: But let us who know nothing of such warfare concede nothing, in judging of his spirit, to the spirit of our unbelieving age, which has no censures except for the defenders of truth:—  "Eternal smiles its emptiness betray,  As shallow streams run dimpling all the way".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:196
verses.text: Bon Dieu, bon diable, as the French say, is the creed of the times.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:197
verses.text: Every one who insults the faith of Christians, who betrays truths he was sworn to defend, who washes his hands but then gives Christ over to be crucified, must be treated with especial favour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:198
verses.text: Christ is good: so is Pilate; and Judas must not be censured.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:199
verses.text: My soul be with Hippolytus when the great Judge holds his assize.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:200
verses.text: His eulogy is in the psalm: "Then stood up Phinehas, and executed judgment: and so the plague was stayed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:201
verses.text: And that was counted unto him for righteousness unto all generations, for evermore".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:202
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:203
verses.text: (As if he had not sinned, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:204
verses.text: )  There is an ambiguity in the facts as given in the Edinburgh edition, of which it is hard to relieve the text.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:205
verses.text: The word καθίστασθαι is rendered to retain (their places) in the first instance, as if the case were all one with the second instance, where μένειν is justly rendered to continue.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:206
verses.text: The second case seems, then, to cover all the ground.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:207
verses.text: What need to speak of men "twice or thrice married," if a man once married, after ordination is not to be retained? The word retained is questionable in the first instance; and I have adopted Wordsworth's reading, to be enrolled, which is doubtless the sense.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:208
verses.text: This statement of our author lends apparent countenance to the antiquity of the "Apostolic Constitutions," so called.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:209
verses.text: Perhaps Hippolytus really supposed them to be apostolic.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:210
verses.text: By Canon XVII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:211
verses.text: of that collection, a man twice married, after baptism cannot be "on the sacerdotal list at all".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:212
verses.text: By Canon XXVI.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:213
verses.text: , an unmarried person once admitted to the clergy cannot be permitted to marry.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:214
verses.text: These are the two cases referred to by our author.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:215
verses.text: In the Greek churches this rule holds to this day; and the Council of Nice refused to prohibit the married clergy to live in that holy estate, while allowing the traditional discipline which Hippolytus had in view in speaking of a violation of the twenty-sixth traditional canon as a sin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:216
verses.text: As Bingham has remarked, however, canons of discipline may be relaxed when not resting on fundamental and scriptural laws.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:217
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:218
verses.text: (Attempt to call themselves a Catholic Church, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:219
verses.text: )  The Callistians, it seems, became a heretical sect, and yet presumed to call themselves a "Catholic Church".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:220
verses.text: Yet this sect, while Callistus lived, was in full communion with the Bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:221
verses.text: Such communion, then, was no test of Catholicity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:222
verses.text: Observe the enormous crimes of which this lawless one was guilty; he seems to antedate the age of Theodora's popes and Marozia's, and what Hippolytus would have said of them is not doubtful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:223
verses.text: It is remarkable that he employed St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:224
verses.text: Paul's expression, however, ὁ ἄνομος, "that wicked" or that "lawless one," seeing, in such a bishop, what St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:225
verses.text: Gregory did in another,—"a forerunner of the Antichrist".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:226
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:227
verses.text: (Callistians, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:228
verses.text: )  Bunsen remarks that Theodoret speaks of this sect under the head of the "Noetians".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:229
verses.text: Wordsworth quotes as follows:  "Callistus took the lead in propagating this heresy after Noetus, and devised certain additions to the impiety of the doctrine".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:230
verses.text: In other words, he was not merely a heretic, but himself a heresiarch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:231
verses.text: He gives the whole passage textually, and institutes interesting parallelisms between the Philosophumena and Theodoret, who used our author, and boldly borrowed from him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:232
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:233
verses.text: (The cause of all things, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:234
verses.text: )  When one looks at the infinite variety of opinions, phrases, ideas, and the like, with which the heresies of three centuries threatened to obscure, defile, and destroy the revelations of Holy Scripture, who can but wonder at the miracle of orthodoxy? Note with what fidelity the good fight of faith was maintained, the depositum preserved, and the Gospel epitomized at last in the Nicaeno-Constantinopolitan definitions, which Professor Shedd, as I have previously noted, declares to be the accepted confession of all the reformed, reputed orthodox, as well as of Greeks and Latins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:235
verses.text: Let us not be surprised, that, during these conflicts, truth on such mysterious subjects was reflected from good men's minds with slight variations of expression.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:236
verses.text: Rather behold the miracle of their essential agreement, and of their entire harmony in the Great Symbol, universally accepted as the testimony of the ante-Nicene witnesses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:237
verses.text: The Word was Himself the cause of all created things; Himself increate; His eternal generation implied in the eternity of His existence and His distinct personality.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:238
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:239
verses.text: (Tartarus, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:240
verses.text: )  I am a little surprised at the innocent statement of the learned translator, that "Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:241
verses.text: Wordsworth justifies Hippolytus' use of this word".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:242
verses.text: It must have occurred to every student of the Greek Testament that St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:243
verses.text: Peter justifies this use in the passage quoted by Wordsworth, which one would think must be self-suggested to any theologian reading our author's text.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:244
verses.text: In short, Hippolytus quotes the second Epistle of St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:245
verses.text: Peter (ii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:246
verses.text: ) when he uses this otherwise startling word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:247
verses.text: Josephus also employs it; it was familiar to the Jews, and the apostle had no scruple in adopting a word which proves the Gentile world acquainted with a Gehenna as well as a Sheol.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:248
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:249
verses.text: (For Christ is the God, p.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:250
verses.text: )  Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:251
verses.text: Wordsworth justly censures Bunsen for his rendering of this passage, also for manufacturing for Hippolytus a "Confession of Faith" out of his tenth book.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:252
verses.text: I must refer the student to that all-important chapter in Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:253
verses.text: Wordsworth's work (cap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:254
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:255
verses.text: ) on the "Development of Christian Doctrine".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:256
verses.text: It is masterly, as against Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:257
verses.text: Newman, as well; and the respectful justice which he renders at the same time to Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:258
verses.text: Bunsen is worthy of all admiration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:259
verses.text: Let it be noted, that, while one must be surprised by the ready command of literary and theological materials which the learned doctor and chevalier brings into instantaneous use for his work, it is hardly less surprising, in spite of all that, that he was willing to throw off his theories and strictures, without any delay, during the confusions of that memorable year , when I had the honour of meeting him among London notabilities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:260
verses.text: He says to his "dearest friend, Archdeacon Hare,…Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:261
verses.text: Tregelles informed me last week of the appearance of the work (of Hippolytus)…I procured a copy in consequence, and perused it as soon as I could; and I have already arrived at conclusions which seem to me so evident that I feel no hesitation in expressing them to you at once".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:262
verses.text: These conclusions were creditable to his acumen and learning in general; eminently so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:263
verses.text: But the theories he had so hastily conceived, in other particulars, crop out in so many crudities of theological caprice, that nobody should try to study his theoretical opinions without the aid of that calm reviewal they have received from Dr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies X and Elucidations 1:264
verses.text: Wordsworth's ripe and sober scholarship and well-balanced intellect.
